key_points: US military chiefs sent a statement to all US military members condemning the Capitol insurrection.
The statement was signed by all eight members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
They described the January 6, 2021 riot as a direct assault on the U.S. Congress, the Capitol building, and the Constitutional process.
The letter emphasized that the rights of freedom of speech and assembly do not justify violence, sedition, and insurrection.
Military leaders warned service members against impeding President-elect Joe Biden’s inauguration.
The letter reminds service members that any act to disrupt the Constitutional process is against the law.

Joint Chiefs Chair Army Gen. Mark Milley and the other chiefs felt compelled to address the issue partly because some veterans and possibly active-duty troops were allegedly involved in the Capitol attack.
The military leaders aim to maintain the apolitical nature of the armed services.
Historically, the Joint Chiefs tend to speak out on highly egregious matters.
The military chiefs reaffirmed their commitment to supporting and defending the Constitution and the forthcoming inauguration of Joe Biden as the 46th Commander in Chief.
